reviews.text: A story about the evils of a greedy corporation owned and operated by men that functions as a real-world celebration of that corporation. What makes that cognitive dissonance all the more sinister is that Barbie is a glorious motion picture.
reviews.author: Kyle Logan

reviews.text: With an overload of pink (not that we’re complaining), the film took over theatres globally with its timely and heartfelt messaging.
reviews.author: Tanzim Pardiwalla

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's film blazes its way into a strange and bold future where adapting a film from a corporate toy franchise doesn’t immediately feel ugly and anti-art.
reviews.author: Christina Newland

reviews.text: The world’s most famous doll turns her thoughts to more existential, philosophical matters in Greta Gerwig’s Barbie, a jazzy and infectiously vibrant summer blockbuster.
reviews.author: William Stottor

reviews.text: Gerwig and Baumbach offer thoughtful commentary not only on Barbie herself and everything she represents, but also on womanhood, feminism, and growing up.
reviews.author: Branyan Towe

reviews.text: Add it all up and we get an enchanting explosion of pink cotton candy fun, all of which conceals a deceptively nutritious sociopolitical core.
reviews.author: Calum Cooper

reviews.text: Can we all just “Beach”?
reviews.author: Dana Barbuto

reviews.text: Barbie is equal parts a feminist rallying cry, an educational film, a reaffirmation of healthy matriarchal values, a musical, a comedy, and the kind of movie that everyone, especially young men, should see.
reviews.author: Joonatan Itkonen

reviews.text: Beneath all the laughs at the expense of men and women is the sad truth that this brand of essentialism itself, of separating Barbies from Kens, of emphasizing their differences, is the thing that damages us the most.
reviews.author: Juan Barquin

reviews.text: Before she hits the road, being in Barbie Land is just as pleasurable for the viewer as it is for these toys. The depiction of this world is a triumph of imaginative design and skilful craftsmanship.
reviews.author: Philip Concannon

reviews.text: That Gerwig was able to essentially hijack a two-hour toy commercial (and a magnificently visualized one at that), one that cost $150 million, and deliver something approximating a progressive message, is just short of miraculous.
reviews.author: Pete Vonder Haar

reviews.text: Throw in Billie Eilish’s melancholic tear-jerker and an intentionally butchered pronunciation of The Godfather and the movie was bound to be an instant classic. And you, too, have the power to take your Birkenstocks out of the closet in 2024.
reviews.author: Nina Braca

reviews.text: One of the main keys to Barbie’s success is commitment to the Barbieland authenticity and Gerwig’s willingness to undercut both Barbie and Ken leads, only to build them back up again.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Peterson

reviews.text: Barbie’s highs more than make up for its shaky third act. The game cast’s commitment to the tone, dazzling visuals and spirited direction prove it’s not a bad thing visiting Barbie’s World even if it’s just a break from the real one.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: One of the most thought-provoking social commentaries and empowering mainstream comedies in recent years. The “I’m Just Ken” scene should be playing on a loop in the Louvre.
reviews.author: Kiko Martinez

reviews.text: Gerwig had given no indication she (or anybody, really) could produce such a hot-pink masterpiece of goofball humor, winsome Jacques Tati alienation, and low-key patriarchy seminar.
reviews.author: Chris Barsanti

reviews.text: Barbie is very entertaining and despite the apparent artificiality, it questions social mandates. Throughout the film, a successful sense of humor is maintained regarding the struggle of the sexes and its cultural implications, without being offensive.
reviews.author: Denise Pieniazek

reviews.text: In Greta we trust.
reviews.author: Brian Gill

reviews.text: With a stellar cast of actors, Barbie focuses all the energy of its first half hour on running through this insular version of things. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Aglaia Berlutti

reviews.text: Barbie is a brand extension exercise, but it's an audacious, hilarious, and artistically crafted one, raising the bar considerably for big-budget intellectual property ventures to come.
reviews.author: Ella Feldman

reviews.text:
"Barbie" is to feminism as a wrench is to a cat.

Extermination of rational thought is this commercial's goal. 

Toxic.

"Barbie" is a chunky diarrhea stain on humanity.

Greta Gerwig is a hack screenwriter, and a remedial filmmaker at best.
reviews.author: Cole Smithey

reviews.text: "Barbie" does exactly what the doll itself was intended to do. It acts as a beacon to young women telling them that they can achieve greatness and be anything they want even in a patriarchal landscape where men control the levers of power.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: For all the great things Robbie and Gosling are doing on a comedic level, their brilliance lies in the ability to also bring pathos to a narrative that never shies away from the complicated nature accepting another's lived experience and desires.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: Every choice here—every line, every prop, every idea—is at once thoughtful and fun, for a moving meditation on womanhood delivered as a singular cinematic experience.
reviews.author: Annlee Ellingson

reviews.text: Barbie isn't just about the doll. Barbie is an explosion of concepts made into a movie, which will make you change your perspective on life, yes, Barbie is a movie that changes lives, and that's what that's what cinema is for. {Full review in Spanish}
reviews.author: Laura Hiros

reviews.text: A sassy comedy that raises questions for people of all ages about what it means to frame your life as a quest.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: Barbie is feminism 101, but for the global mainstream audience who have been served nothing but depoliticised superheroes for decades, the directness of Barbie's feminism is an essential step for reclaiming the soul of the Hollywood blockbuster.
reviews.author: Joseph Fahim

reviews.text: [Barbie] takes our complicated real-world relationship to Barbie and uses it as a metaphor to interrogate the impossibly high, often contradictory standards women are held to in our male-dominated culture.
reviews.author: Griffin Schiller

reviews.text: To watch Barbie is to feel totally and completely seen. And that's what makes Barbie worthy of the wait.
reviews.author: Patricia Karounos

reviews.text: The laughs are plentiful and the set design is eye-popping, but what makes Barbie truly work is its deft tackling of numerous themes.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Barbie boasts impressive production design, costumes, and a pair of leads up to the task of bringing their respective dolls to life, but sadly comes up a little short when it comes to its screenplay.
reviews.author: Jeff Beck

reviews.text: The film’s boldness and, frankly, weirdness, allows Barbie to become a successful sum of its parts. It’s a film that clearly has something to say and doesn’t want audiences to get caught up in the fact that it’s a doll at the center of it.
reviews.author: Monique Jones

reviews.text: One of the best films of the year in cinematographic terms, probably the best comedy that we have seen in a long time, and an extraordinarily entertaining product that promotes the value of searching for a more cohesive society. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sergio Burstein

reviews.text: Gerwig and Baumbach lure viewers with the promise of squeaky clean pop-culture fun, all while Trojan-horsing a stranger, more complex battle of the sexes.
reviews.author: Rubén Rosario

reviews.text: Barbie is a dazzling new instant classic and unlike anything you’ve seen before. It’s the perfect summer movie and one of the funniest of the year.
reviews.author: Anthony Gagliardi

reviews.text: Though presented as a funny comedy about the doll that we all know, in reality, it is a very fine and brave portrait of what it means to be a man and a woman today. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sara Heredia

reviews.text: Early-on, "Barbie” resembles those Frankie Avalon and Annette Funicello beach party movies. It's breezily photographed in pop art colors by Rodrigo Prieto. In Barbieland, the houses don’t have walls and everybody seems happy. Mellow whimsy prevails.
reviews.author: Michael Calleri

reviews.text: It explores the frailties of masculinity and the post-feminist struggle to escape the matrix of utopian feminism, even though Barbie and Ken's journey of self-discovery sometimes misses the point of fun. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: It's the rare film that's as intelligent as it is entertaining.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: ...[Greta] Gerwig’s pink, plastic epic is infused with its director’s indie spirit and far more cognizant of the toy’s complicated legacy than you might expect.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Zhang

reviews.text: The film gets a little lost at times, as if it had too many storylines to play with and won’t let any of them go... But there are many great jokes in the film.
reviews.author: Michael Wood

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig has created a coming-of-age feminist self-aware masterpiece in Barbie with a heart of gold that both subverts and matches expectations.
reviews.author: Nadine Whitney

reviews.text: Barbie isn’t as streamlined as my favorite girl comedies, but it’s more thematically ambitious than many of them too. And I’ll take flawed ambition over plastic perfection any day of the week.
reviews.author: Caroline Siede

reviews.text: All is peaceful and idyllic, that is until Stereotypical Barbie inexplicably blurts out a passing thought about death.
reviews.author: Rick Romancito

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's summer blockbuster is well worth watching, but fails to reach the storytelling heights of her previous work.
reviews.author: Sandeep Sandhu

reviews.text: This funny, eye-catching film sports pitch-perfect performances from Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling, paying tribute to the iconic toy while skewering the patriarchy and feminist window-dressing.
reviews.author: Valerie Kalfrin

reviews.text: Gerwig didn’t just make a great movie; it’s something that will buckle the knees and tug hard on the heartstrings for generations of viewers. This is the work of a marvelous filmmaker who knows exactly what she is and wants to do.
reviews.author: Dan Buffa

reviews.text: Serious and lightweight at the same time, Barbie proves surprisingly successful, much like the doll that inspired.
reviews.author: Robin Holabird

reviews.text: Barbie is not a perfect movie, but it is a conversation, and a conversation worth having. For me, Barbie brought the unexpected pleasure of finding shared experiences in our fractured, factious age.
reviews.author: Kathryn Reklis

reviews.text: While these existential questions are refreshing in a mainstream movie, the real magic is found in how they move toward maturity: through imperfection and mistake.
reviews.author: Hannah Anderson

reviews.text: The story is simple and sweet.
reviews.author: Mikkel Snyder

reviews.text: [Gerwig] and partner Noah Baumbach have penned a very clever script that packs in humour, sadness, satire and a powerful feminist message.
reviews.author: Ian Bunting

reviews.text: Barbie, the movie, might make a few missteps as a feminist polemic, but it largely succeeds as a gleefully subversive look at the dehumanizing effects of inequality and how a simple idea can change the world.
reviews.author: Paul Kanieski

reviews.text: Barbie is full of laughs and lots of pink! But the one thing that stood out to me the most were the messages within the movie. While the film was very meta in many ways it brought a lot of  much needed women's rights issues to the forefront!
reviews.author: Matthew Haynes

reviews.text: In the new film, “Barbie,” Greta Gerwig paints a world where anything is possible, where girls can realize ambitions, dream big and call the shots – not unlike the activity that has swirled around the toy for decades.
reviews.author: Bruce R. Miller

reviews.text: Barbie‘s downfall is triggered by a midsection that grows less and less interesting (and more and more grating) as time progresses...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: The film is a wicked satire of all that the Barbie franchise stands for; at the same time, it is never mean spirited. In fact, it’s a celebration. A balancing act for the ages.
reviews.author: Robert W. Butler

reviews.text: I can’t imagine seeing it a second time, because everything is right there on the surface (except for the Mattel Easter eggs, I guess), easy to grasp and easy enough to enjoy. And that’s it.
reviews.author: Robert Horton

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig, seeking to forge a distinguished persona for Barbie, one that steps beyond the corporate machinations and transnational interests of Mattel, secures a delicate equilibrium that noticeably tips in her favor.
reviews.author: Ryan Oquiza

reviews.text: There's a winking sense of humor that I really enjoyed.
reviews.author: Manuel Betancourt

reviews.text: It is in many ways reverential to Barbie, and in other ways subversive. It's kind of amazing that it manages to do both.
reviews.author: Lael Loewenstein

reviews.text: This first live-action Barbie film is not, as some may assume, for kids, but more for the teenagers and adults who have played with the doll in the past
reviews.author: Sarah Vincent

reviews.text: It was supposed to matter that those values were feminist and not just consumerist...
reviews.author: A.S. Hamrah

reviews.text: The first forty minutes were hilarious and then it started to taper off a bit, particularly things with America's daughter. The leads did an amazing job and the musical numbers were weird and fun.
reviews.author: Justin Brown

reviews.text: Kudos to Greta Gerwig for balancing a talented cast with different comedy sensibilities into a cohesive, hilarious and thought provoking film that made me examine my own biases.
reviews.author: Brandon Collins

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig’s pink-plastic jab at the patriarchy is one of the most subversive films of the year, possibly the decade. It's also one of the most philosophically rich.
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: Barbie is a good time at the movies. The nearly two-hour runtime flies by and is jam-packed with incredible set pieces and endless imagination.
reviews.author: Justine Smith

reviews.text: Gerwig’s pacey direction of her own co-written script delivers 114 minutes of neon-pink absurdity, big musical numbers, genuine belly laughs and sly, self-aware digs at popular culture.
reviews.author: Chris Newbould

reviews.text: At its core, Gerwig’s film delivers a surprisingly strong emotional hook in Barbie’s conundrum of being caught between her idyllic plastic life and the ever-changing, complicated real world.
reviews.author: Jack Murphy

reviews.text: There are many references that the movie makes to aspects of pop culture, and to discover them all one would need to give it a second look [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Gisela Savdie

reviews.text: BARBIE is a cinematic phenomenon that pulls off the rarest of feats: using a doll to make a striking commentary about gender politics. Greta Gerwig levels up as a director and writer with Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling delivering career best performances.
reviews.author: John Rocha

reviews.text: It's hard to understand getting angry about a film like Barbie. It's such a joyously bonkers, rip-roaringly hilarious, and yes very pinkly-coloured piece of pure unbridled entertainment.
reviews.author: Ilan Preskovsky

reviews.text: This Barbie movie might be too candied and flamboyant but is certainly not silly.
reviews.author: Filipe Freitas

reviews.text: Barbie, while far from perfect, is an unexpectedly delightful breath of fresh and campy air with a reasonably well-delivered feminist message.
reviews.author: Gregg Shapiro

reviews.text: With a final line that's one of the best in the business, Barbie shows it's possible to both deconstruct the ideal and keep the manufacturer onside with a script that is a masterful balancing act, some subtle, smart direction and some terrific actors
reviews.author: Jane Freebury

reviews.text: Barbie is a small miracle. [Full review in Portuguese]
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: Signaling the reach and limitations of a feminist point of view beleaguered by a consumerism that assimilates and trivializes social causes... the film simultaneously mirrors it and questions it blandly. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Carlos Bonfil

reviews.text: If Barbie were made 15 or even 10 years ago I would have eaten it up like a perfectly toasted waffle with a dollop of cream. Instead, being feministsplained about the patriarchy & gender inequality every 5 minutes soured me to it
reviews.author: Scarlett Harris

reviews.text: Better than I could have ever expected a Barbie movie to be.
reviews.author: Kent Garrison

reviews.text: It’s unfortunate that in a film where she goads her characters to find themselves, director Greta Gerwig's creative voice is flattened out by a corporation’s.
reviews.author: Tatsam Mukherjee

reviews.text: This is what happens when you don't do a satire correctly. Barbie is what happens when capitalism dictates messages about girlhood, feminism, and gender inequality.
reviews.author: Alachia Queen

reviews.text: Gracefully combines the lightness of cotton candy entertainment with the cleverness of a well-crafted plot
reviews.author: Frank Wilkins

reviews.text: Barbie is Gerwig’s weirdest, funniest and most bonkers film to date. Within the studio system, we should all be very grateful it exists.
reviews.author: Maria Lattila

reviews.text: When I became a father I searched for movies that would show my daughter positive role models, and it was tough going. Barbie makes up for lost time and should warm the hearts of parents and daughters alike.
reviews.author: Leonard Maltin

reviews.text: ...portrays the message that men need women but women, most of the time, only need themselves, but I doubt most will be offended as the harshness is done in a loving and humorous manner that we men are not supposed to understand in the first place.
reviews.author: Danny Minton

reviews.text: In a world where blockbuster films are surrounded by digital landscapes, Barbie’s devotion to practical production is outstanding.
reviews.author: Damian Levy

reviews.text: It might not land perfectly for every single member of its audience, but at its core, “Barbie” is a movie packed with joy, and a blast of fun at the movies this summer.
reviews.author: Matthew Jackson

reviews.text: Barbie performs a great trick: it takes in crowds aching for fantasy and switches the script, telling them that reality and their flawed, beautiful selves is all they have to love.
reviews.author: Rebecca Liu

reviews.text: Barbie is, at best, half a movie.
reviews.author: Eleanor Ringel Cater

reviews.text: If you don’t like one gag, stick around, another is on the way.
reviews.author: Joe Lapointe

reviews.text: The Barbie flick struts self-awareness, luring us all in. But humor falters by act three, like an SNL skit past its prime. Fear not, for Ryan Gosling's charismatic portrayal of Ken almost rescues the day... but not quite!
reviews.author: John Flickinger

reviews.text: Robbie and Ryan Gosling as Ken were superb casting. They both can project a very plastic emotional shell or be internally damaged when needed.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: Race, culture, sexuality and other parts of identity were left in its original packaging lowering the overall impact and highlighting the heavy handed focus on the gender binary.
reviews.author: KT Mahe

reviews.text: It is clever and funny at times. The look of the movie, with its vibrant Barbieland colors, is a wonderful change from the bland way most movies look nowadays.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Slathered with satire that isn’t sugar-coated, Barbie’s message hits hard.
reviews.author: Neil Soans

reviews.text: The film tries to do too much, but we can’t be anything less than deeply impressed that anyone came up with too many smart, funny, biting things to say in a movie about Barbie, of all things.
reviews.author: Tom Fitzgerald and Lorenzo Marquez

reviews.text: “Barbie” is the perfect brand to tell this story. An unexpected exploration of the value of being a human being, how we shouldn’t be solely defined by our gender and the pros and cons of both matriarchy and patriarchy
reviews.author: Rosa Parra

reviews.text: This film is pink on estrogen! It is a smart, fun and important look at an American Icon. It humorously portrays male figures like Ken as accessories in Barbie Land, but the focus remains on highlighting Barbie's importance rather than vilifying men.
reviews.author: Reginald Ponder

reviews.text: Barbie has a lot of good qualities. ... The problem is that a little amount of Barbie and Ken goes a long way, and the film eventually comes off as one-note. Barbie could have been a great Saturday Night Live skit.
reviews.author: Tim Miller

reviews.text: A fearless feminist manifesto that’s perfectly wrapped in a pretty pink bow, the film is a defiant, thought-provoking, brutally honest exploration of the female experience.
reviews.author: Louisa Moore

reviews.text: Margot Robbie stars as Stereotypical Barbie with Ryan Gosling is her Ken, but the film doesn’t live up to the hype.
reviews.author: Prathyush Parasuraman

reviews.text: Gosling walks away with the film, both through the patriarchy and his hilariously sincere performance. Overall, it’s one hell of an achievement. It’s just not the one we were looking for.
reviews.author: Sarah Manvel

reviews.text: The good news is that Barbie is an excellent film and is possibly the cinematic event of the summer. In leading their team, Margot Robbie and Greta Gerwig have made a smart and sunny blockbuster with something to say.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: In trying to say too much, the film winds up not saying much at all.
reviews.author: Tarpley Hitt

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig tackles philosophical questions that are more daunting than a film based on a children’s toy can handle. It results in a strange, uneven, but beautiful movie.
reviews.author: Erin Schwartz

reviews.text: The film goes beyond an ideological corset, yet it remains faithful to its framework as a comedy about marketing fiction. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juan José Beteta

reviews.text: Just enjoy the performances by fine actors having a ball in fabulous costumes on outrageous sets. And if you or your little sisters come away with some meaty food for thought, more power to it. It can be many things to many people. That's the glory of it.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: Much deeper than its superficial pink packaging. Greta Gerwig cleverly comments on the complex gender dynamics of a popular toy brand that has so many inherent contradictions. Listen closely and you’ll hear the box office shouting: “Closer I am to fine!”
reviews.author: Jason Fraley

reviews.text: Barbie is strained and smug without much wit. One should bear in mind that Mattel, with revenue of $42 billion in 2022, partnered with Warner Bros. on the making of the movie.
reviews.author: Joanne Laurier

reviews.text: Sadly, Barbie isn’t the brilliant film that many hoped it would be. The cheesy comedy often gets in the way of what could have been a very important storyline and to be honest many will expect more from a Gerwig film.
reviews.author: David Griffiths

reviews.text: Barbie, the doll, not the movie, is made of contradictions and Gerwig has done a mighty fine job of giving those contradictions the sparkliest, shiniest, warmest visual avatar.
reviews.author: Mini Anthikad-Chhibber

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig serves up a frothy confection of fashion and fun coupled with searing social critique of the iconic doll in the movie Barbie.
reviews.author: Sheri Flanders

reviews.text: With a clever opening sequence and an excellent cast, Barbie manages to overcome cumbersome plotting and feminist pieties to provide a delightful spectacle of funny moments that add up to something pretty good.
reviews.author: Eileen Jones

reviews.text: Amid all the pink, there’s plenty of room for a think.
reviews.author: Alison Gillmor

reviews.text: Through the film’s satirical insights about modern society, the director asks all the right questions.
reviews.author: Devesh Sharma

reviews.text: Barbie was solid -- it was a good time [with a] great message.
reviews.author: Tony Baker

reviews.text: 'Barbie' actually turns examining the toy’s impact on generations of girls and women into its whole raison d’être.
reviews.author: André Hereford

reviews.text: For every nod and wink it offers the audience, there is also an urgent call to attention simmering beneath those barbed and razor-sharp quips and puns.
reviews.author: Michael Ward

reviews.text: Is Barbie a goofy romp or a heady subversion of genre?
reviews.author: Allie Gregory

reviews.text: The film may skew towards girls but there’s more than enough story, laughs and pratfalls for boys and their dads to embrace.
reviews.author: Neely Swanson

reviews.text: Gerwig’s satire and the comedic chops of Robbie and, especially, Gosling fall into perfect rhythm once Barbie and Ken leave the candy-colored comforts of Barbie Land and Ken discovers the patriarchy.
reviews.author: Adam Kempenaar

reviews.text: Margot Robbie and Greta Gerwig have created an edgy, existential, empowering comedy-adventure that cleverly exposes our sexist societal shortcomings.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: The story of Barbieland’s descent into a patriarchal nightmare ... fails at the most basic level of prompting laughs. This is a mild problem for a film that is ostensibly a comedy.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: BARBIE was always destined to deconstruct the long-lasting stereotypes around perfectionism with Barbie, but the way Greta Gerwig does that still blew away all expectations.
reviews.author: JD Duran

reviews.text: Barbie is a lunatic fable about girlhood, good vibes, and going for it that proposes self-acceptance as the most radical act of self-love, told by a doll—person? Yes!—that is positive and problematic at the same time.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: Barbie is vibrant and refreshingly creative with its heavy-handed messaging. It's a shame they fell a bit short with bringing the message to a fully satisfying conclusion. A satire that's not gonna resonate with everyone...but what satire ever does?
reviews.author: Cody Leach

reviews.text: Barbie is pulp and just as well - it never ceases to be enjoyable.
reviews.author: Saibal Chatterjee

reviews.text: Director Greta Gerwig achieves the feat of a delivering a big budget Barbie movie with smart and subversive social commentary, all wrapped up in a hot pink cotton candy camp valentine.
reviews.author: Loren King

reviews.text: Gerwig finds enough laughs to keep anyone from trying to plumb any depths or wonder whether the plot makes any sense at all
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Barbie is a very hip movie with something to say, but the narrative leaves so little room for nuance and interpretation that you walk out with more questions than curiosities.
reviews.author: Michael J. Casey

reviews.text: In Barbie, Greta Gerwig presents a genuine and candid vision. She dramatizes the anguish of adult life, yet transforms it into a relaxed experience, with moments of comedy and musical interludes. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Lily Dreven

reviews.text: Gerwig’s Barbie isn’t trying to create a Feminist World Order, she’s merely using a well-known character to exaggerate society’s flaws. The message of this movie really is equality and regaining the balance of power.
reviews.author: Amelia Harvey

reviews.text: Gerwig’s glee as a director is evident... It’s a lot to take in, and some skits work better than others. But if you consider this movie to be a package deal, the package is wrapped nice and tight -- but not perfectly.
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: It’s funny, it’s bright and uplifting, and I think has a lot to say about the modern world – both in terms of feminism and gender equality. Ryan Gosling really goes all-out.
reviews.author: Victoria Luxford

reviews.text: [Robbie] takes this amorphous idea of the Barbie doll and finds her heart and soul, and makes her a fully realized woman. And I’ll be damned if the guy [Gosling] doesn’t nearly steal the movie from her.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: This production manages to fit in a pop show, absurd comedy, feminist content, parody, and Greta Gerwig's auteurist sensibility. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Loser

reviews.text: It is a pop culture phenomenon that has taken over the moment by introducing modern femininity to viewers willing to ditch streaming and head to theaters. It’s campy, introspective, fun, and emotional all in one movie.
reviews.author: Matthew Creith

reviews.text: The creativity in the script by Gerwig and her husband Noah Baumbach is the highlight and is sure to garner awards consideration in that category.
reviews.author: Dustin Chase

reviews.text: Just as fun as it looks. Director Greta Gerwig makes the Barbie world really come to life in a way that would have been disastrous in other hands.
reviews.author: Paul Salfen

reviews.text: "Barbie" is confusing! This allegorical farce ultimately affirms the matriarchy, so it logically follows that "Barbie" is inherently transphobic. So why are there trans-Barbies? Who the heck knows what Gerwig is trying to say here? It's quite fun though!
reviews.author: Mark Jackson

reviews.text: Bright and sparkly but ultimately doesn't satisfy.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: Mostly, Barbie is laugh-out-loud funny and a sheer delight.
reviews.author: Max Weiss

reviews.text: A consistently engaging comedy driven by wacky production design, joyful musical numbers, and goofy and committed performances.
reviews.author: Margot Harrison

reviews.text: It would be churlish to deny the charm of Gerwig’s buoyant creation. In an age when genuine cinematic joy is rare, we’re all lucky to be passengers in Barbie’s hot-pink plastic convertible.
reviews.author: Bennett Campbell Ferguson

reviews.text: The final cut is a paradox of ideas: superficial yet smart, caustic yet clever, and showcasing not just the very best but even the worst... no doll is left behind... Barbie still has the ability to become whatever girls need her to be...
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: I couldn’t help thinking about how Barbie has already been a big-screen character in Toy Story 2 and Toy Story 3, where the filmmakers used her more cleverly than anything that is done here.
reviews.author: Hannah Brown

reviews.text: The film is proof that Barbie’s longevity as a cultural icon is a marvelous yet mysteriously resilient thing. Gerwig’s hard-edged but affectionate paean is sweeter than it is satirical, slightly more perky than political.
reviews.author: Peg Aloi

reviews.text: Barbie was doomed from the start.
reviews.author: Kelly Vance

reviews.text: Its patriarchal theme creates the perfect sandbox for a movie like this to play in. It’s the clunky execution, the surface-level storytelling.... and the complete lack of restraint that ultimately weighs the movie down.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig proves trustworthy in her interpretation and adaptation of reality.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud

reviews.text: Barbie is an invitation to take uncertainty by the hand, enjoy the vanilla, the ordinary; no longer the brilliance of Barbieland, but the opacity of what we yet don't understand. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fabiola Santiago

reviews.text: Give Gosling the Oscar.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: Oh, to have been in the Gerwig/Baumbach house while they wrote this inspired silliness!
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: Barbie is a healing cinema experience that explores the psyche of not being enough while delivering an infectious performance that makes us feel like we could do anything.
reviews.author: Alicia Gilstorf

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's magnum opus is a brilliantly funny rallying cry for decency and shredding hypocrisies. There's not a laughless minute to be had with Robbie and Gosling nailing every gag and emotion with an equally inspired ensemble.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: Depending on your perspective, Barbie is either anathema to the feminist movement, or a great asset. Somehow, Gerwig and Baumbach have managed to incorporate both views into this film.
reviews.author: John McDonald

reviews.text: Squarely take(s) aim at millennial angst about our place in an ever-changing world that isn't as good as the one we thought we were building.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: Seriously, how did this movie get made? All...hail...Greta Gerwig.
reviews.author: Bob Grimm

reviews.text: An existential crisis wrapped in a hot pink bow, Gerwig's Barbie is a hilarious, subversive romp. While it can't address as many issues as the plastic protagonists would posit, it's still forging the way.
reviews.author: Dana Han-Klein

reviews.text: For the constraints that I'm sure were in place...I'm pretty impressed.
reviews.author: Joseph Robinson

reviews.text: Barbie is hilariously meta, containing spectacularly funny musical numbers, and an efficient tonal balance between over-the-top comedy and rich, thought-provoking social commentary.
reviews.author: Manuel São Bento

reviews.text: Barbie is a phenomenally funny, smart, really engaging film.
reviews.author: tt stern-enzi

reviews.text: Robbie perfectly embodies Barbie, but Gosling easily steals the spotlight with his hilarious Kenergy. The movie works best when it operates as a deliriously fun fantasy comedy.
reviews.author: Ruth Maramis

reviews.text: Things end with an attempt to bring Barbie’s origin story full-circle, but the transition is clunky, and it suggests this was just supposed to be a Legally Blonde-style take on the Pinnochio tale all along.
reviews.author: Lina Lecaro

reviews.text: A candy-colored Trojan Horse into the heart of contemporary culture and features superb and layered performances.
reviews.author: John Paul King

reviews.text: This is absolutely sensational, and anyone who can’t vibe with the sharp, empathetic commentary here has got to grow up. This really is one of the best IP films ever.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: "Barbie" is well worth seeing on the big screen. This campy mix of genres is a summer blockbuster for a reason and will be a perfect position for both young adults and those who have outgrown playing with dolls but wish to reminisce.
reviews.author: Zofia Wijaszka

reviews.text: Gerwig turns in a comedy that lightly approaches topics that, outside the screen, adhere to a higher gravity.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Hugo Hernández Valdivia

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig manages to reconcile corporate interests with those of her own filmography. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alejandro Alemán

reviews.text: Barbie never quite arrives where Gerwig wants it to go. But god, is it fun to watch.
reviews.author: Linda Codega

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's Barbie delivers on the sweetness, satire, and fun performances of its main cast as Mattel's beloved, yet controversial doll lineup.
reviews.author: Ben Wasserman

reviews.text: It's attempting to do many things at once, but does most of them well, most of the time.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: The Barbenheimer phenomenon pleases me primarily because it's proof there is room for an unapologetically pink feminist manifesto next to a deadly serious anti-war story in our existing cineplexes, and that plenty of people will indeed see both.
reviews.author: Rain Jokinen

reviews.text: The ribald humor is just clever enough to please older viewers while flying over younger viewers’ heads.
reviews.author: Erik Kain

reviews.text: The worst thing that could've happened is that Barbie would turn out to be a good product... And unfortunately, it is. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Erick Estrada

reviews.text: Irreverent, superbly acted and beautifully realized, the movie mines the giggles out of Barbie breaking out of the doll’s house.
reviews.author: Nandini Ramnath

reviews.text: Barbie is a movie about Barbie made with the political awareness, consistency, and intelligence of the doll. Perhaps realizing it's in deep water without a swimming lesson...
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: In trying to be comically ahead of the sexism curve, it’s ended up feeling sexist itself.
reviews.author: Camilla Long

reviews.text: Barbie isn't just beautiful pink eye candy. Greta Gerwig delivers an equally funny and compelling story that most will enjoy. While the 3rd act gets muddled tackling several ideas into a neat ending, Margot Robbie & Ryan Gosling make it all worthwhile.
reviews.author: Cris Parker

reviews.text: Their thunderous feminist message is leavened by plenty of sharp gags and, following her acclaimed 2017 film Lady Bird and the wonderful Little Women (2019), Gerwig further burnishes her reputation as a director of terrific flair.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: Gerwig thoughtfully and beautifully explores the uniqueness of women; the feminine in its beauty and in all forms and imperfections. We don’t fit in a box – and never will.
reviews.author: Sara Clements

reviews.text: While Gerwig’s deeper meaning is to give everyone a voice, I worry that the average movie-goer won’t see the forest for the trees, and only take the surface-level message to heart.
reviews.author: Mark Johnson

reviews.text: Regardless of Mattel’s corporate intentions, Gerwig has crafted a warm, funny and cinematically rich film -- if one whose narrative and political ambitions are far less radical than it would like us to suppose.
reviews.author: Christopher Machell

reviews.text: This movie is bold, smart and surprisingly sophisticated. It may look like a silly action adventure, but textured dialog and rapid-fire gags add important layers of meaning that strike a nerve.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: Barbie does something more than just highlight the ridiculous and limiting nature of external and internalized misogyny.
reviews.author: Kayla Kumari Upadhyaya

reviews.text: Gerwig continues to be wildly bold while delivering masterful work!
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: "Barbie" isn’t the satire some may have been hoping for, fangs dripping with pink blood; it’s a classic Horatian satire, tickling its target on the tummy instead of disemboweling it.
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's Barbie is simply delightful. The worldbuilding and set design is incredible, and very nostalgic for those of us who grew up playing with Barbie dolls. Robbie is fantastic, but it is Gosling's Ken that steals the show.
reviews.author: Natasha Alvar

reviews.text: “That felt achey, but good,” Barbie says when a tear escapes her eye for the first time. The impossibility of perfection gives way to an ache in the soul about existence and its doomed fleetingness. That's the essence of Barbie, the essence of life itself
reviews.author: Tina Kakadelis

reviews.text: The message is more powerful than what we can see with the naked eye, but we will not be able to see it if we believe this film is... an 'anti-men' film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rafael Santisteban

reviews.text: The feminist parable doesn’t always make sense and some characters fail to come to life. But, after a raft of over-polished ­blockbusters, this messiness feels ­refreshing
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: Brimming with great gags and vibrant visuals, it’s a dizzying pop o’ culture and universality. Through a smart, clever, and funny script... it is also self-aware and pokes fun at the Barbie ideal and how that has evolved over the years.
reviews.author: Lynn Venhaus

reviews.text: …fun for kids, a mind-blower for thinking adults…
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: The real ideas in the film are enough to make the movie work without the focus on weak men, even though that focus entertains. It brings a weird darkness to the effort because, at core, it’s mean in much the way the film's women feel the world is to them.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: The Barbie movie is thoughtful, funny, and emotional. The dialogue in this movie will have me thinking about it for days to come. Performances, costume, and set design are top-notch.
reviews.author: Wendy Lee Szany

reviews.text: Giddily wrapped in a pretty, rosy-colored package, it's a social satire about our society and and gender relations. Gorgeous, uproarious and ingenious, “Barbie” will be remembered as one of the defining pop culture movies for years to come.
reviews.author: Nathalia Aryani

reviews.text: It's a real good time... it was a weird choice for Greta Gerwig, I think, and yet she's done the absolute best you could probably do with a film like this.
reviews.author: Stephen A. Russell

reviews.text: Barbie goes beyond the marketing for an intellectual property. This isn't just a toy commercial, it's smart and entertaining.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: Robbie infuses Barbie with the exuberance and joy we expected from the portrayal. But the descent into actual life issues is a surprise that the audience never suspects is coming. Gerwig’s visualization is a true feat, right down to Barbie's feet.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: Protective of the Barbie image and more expansive of it.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: A seriously funny, crazily ambitious movie. But 'Barbie' bites off more than it can chew, and only nibbles the hand that feeds.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: In the hands of [Greta] Gerwig, Barbie is far from superfluous—but it’s also not the calibre of movie that I imagined she would deliver.
reviews.author: Akhil Arora

reviews.text: It’s a riotously entertaining candy-coloured feminist fable that manages simultaneously to celebrate, satirise and deconstruct its happy-plastic subject. Audiences will be delighted. Mattel should be ecstatic.
reviews.author: Mark Kermode

reviews.text: Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda minister in charge of the wartime German film industry, believed the most effective use of the medium was to bury the message in ostensibly innocuous genre fare. You sense he’d have found Gerwig’s film a bit much.
reviews.author: Ed Whitfield

reviews.text: [Director] Gerwig doesn’t just seek to make an entertaining movie, but an important one. And in that regard it succeeds.
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: A unique, big budget comedy with auteur sensibilities, that is elevated by talented and committed artists. Very funny, except for when it loses its playfulness to deliver well-intended social commentary in an excessively direct way. [Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nestor Bentancor

reviews.text: I have to give props to Gerwig and Baumbach for managing to paint this film with as much pathos as they do pink.
reviews.author: Hanna Flint

reviews.text: Barbie is the ultimate summer movie for having as much wit and wisdom as it does charm, silliness, and an abundance of pink.
reviews.author: Mark McPherson

reviews.text: Margot Robbie as Barbie is play, joy and fun rolled up into an icon. The script is phenomenal. Costume design make up and hair are extraordinary. Barbie’s dream world on film is what I thought of in my world of play as a girl.
reviews.author: Jeanine T. Abraham

reviews.text: I’ve long believed in the power of Barbie. I’m just glad Gerwig did too.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: A film that presents us with a really interesting story that goes beyond the stereotypes that one might have of these dolls, and that tries to convey valuable messages about social injustices and gender roles. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: One has to hand it to Gerwig for offering up the most counterintuitive ouroboros of an IP franchise-starter imaginable.
reviews.author: Charles Lyons-Burt

reviews.text: Fun, original, and profound, Barbie is a colorful odyssey with great performances, catchy musical numbers, and an incisive social commentary. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rene Sanchez

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig’s Barbie is a love letter to every little girl who grew up fighting something that feels insurmountable to conquer. It’s a bold, bright exploration of existential crises that seem relentless and the hope for something more.
reviews.author: Gissane Sophia

reviews.text: Beginning life as a conceptual head-scratcher, Barbie ended up being one of the year’s best surprise gems.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: After a sweet and funny first 20 minutes, the performance of Ryan Gosling (as the ever-clueless Ken) and a grandly overstated, feminist soliloquy by America Ferrera, as a former Barbie mom, become hip highlights of this more silly than clever movie.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: I have never struggled so much with a "fresh" or "rotten" score. Ultimately, I'm settling on the positive side. Even though Barbie is too long and chalk-full of cringy monologues; the fun cast, wonderful musical numbers and great visuals make up for it.
reviews.author: Adam Olinger

reviews.text: The details of the story seem utterly inseparable from, and continuous with, the riotously ornamental visual realms that it sets into motion.
reviews.author: Richard Brody

reviews.text: A delightful confection at its best, an unfocused jumble at its worst.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: The movie revels in the history of Barbie, from the related dolls that didn’t quite take off to the notion that the doll presents both an impossible physical ideal and yet also allowed the children playing with Barbies to imagine endless possibilities.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: The tonal and narrative balance is handled incredibly well throughout, and, whilst it can’t claim to be perfect and certainly won’t appease everyone, I had a blast and my Kenergy levels were satisfied. Life in plastic really is fantastic, clearly.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: Gerwig leaves a personal imprint on her film, as a boldly painted battle cry for womanhood and subversive social satire about misguided male perceptions.
reviews.author: Elias Savada

reviews.text: Barbie suffers from an over-bloated script that’s trying to tackle too much with too many stars instead of focusing on character development. The marketing was more successful than the movie itself.
reviews.author: Kristen Maldonado

reviews.text: Gerwig has directed a lively, zany, oh-so witty and pretty Barbie flick that's perfectly cast, a costuming showcase and, in Barbie Land, a production-design dream.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: Barbie's middle gets a little soft, but [writers Greta] Gerwig and [Noah] Baumbach ... turn plastic into flesh, tugging at the heartstrings and tickling the funny bone with the year's most vivacious tribute to imaginative play and female empowerment.
reviews.author: Candice McMillan

reviews.text: I fully enjoyed it, although I thought it got too preachy by the end.
reviews.author: Andy Klein

reviews.text: Barbie recognizes its own surreal existence: a world where perfect plastic figures wrestle with humanistic imperfections.
reviews.author: Valerie Complex

reviews.text: Clever and funny – but frustratingly shackled by Mattel’s oversight – this film is a cute diversion but wants to be so much more.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: A cinematic dreamland of pastel eye candy and immaculate dialog, with deeply meaningful messages for all.
reviews.author: Jordy Sirkin

reviews.text: Gerwig and Robbie are both so into the material that their deconstruction of the cultural icon has resulted in a magnificent film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Raquel R. Incertis

reviews.text: in Gerwig’s hands, along with her co-writer Noah Baumbach, it’s sly and just about as subversive as a movie can be.
reviews.author: Alissa Wilkinson

reviews.text: Barbie hits the target on many levels. It’s a fun, whimsical romp with a great message. Robbie is proving to be the true movie star of our time.
reviews.author: Bradley Gibson

reviews.text: It feels like Barbie will be more enjoyable the more you think back on it. Ryan Gosling is outrageously funny and the film fully embraces ridiculous concepts while also intellectually tickling our brains as we question how we socially treat one another.
reviews.author: Chris Sawin

reviews.text: Combining with high-level pop culture and topical gender theory jokes, Gerwig showcases her incredible vision.
reviews.author: Alan French

reviews.text: There is no escaping the onslaught of corporations squeezing profit from every “intellectual property” available. Rage all you want, it’s still going to happen, and this is the best version of what it can be.
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: Barbie is surprisingly spiritual, treating the messiness and contradictions of womanhood with reverence.
reviews.author: Grace Segers

reviews.text: Barbie’s plastic exterior turns out to be extraordinarily human, turning a doll with unrealistic beauty standards that young girls could never relate to into someone every single woman can relate to.
reviews.author: Steph Cozza

reviews.text: Barbie ultimately asks what it means to be mortal, what it means to be alive — and it takes these questions seriously.
reviews.author: Eileen G'Sell

reviews.text: Gerwig and Baumbach somehow make all of these heavy and relevant themes feel accessible and nuanced at the same time. They don’t beat around the bush, as they know that addressing all of this directly while maintaining an air of whimsy will do the job.
reviews.author: Pramit Chatterjee

reviews.text: Barbie is clever, indulgent and fun. Greta plays around with the ideas of patriarchy, puberty, feminism and existentialism like they're from her dollhouse.
reviews.author: Devansh Sharma

reviews.text: Gerwig has delivered a summer entertainment that has plenty of brains in its blonde bombshell.
reviews.author: Alci Rengifo

reviews.text: Barbie is mostly brisk, eye-catching, and entertaining, made with imagination and affection.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: Barbie is one of the most subversive, unexpected summer blockbusters in recent memory.
reviews.author: Kevin Slane

reviews.text: Barbie positions itself as subversive, but by the film’s end, it's unclear what the filmmakers have actually managed to disrupt or undermine beyond our perception of the Mattel corporation.
reviews.author: M.G. Mailloux

reviews.text: Instead of offering a reflection of what it means to be a human living alongside other humans, Gerwig falls into a cliched form of existentialism in which life is essentially meaningless, and it’s up to us to assert our own meaning.
reviews.author: Collin Garbarino

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's surprisingly sharp and satirical spoof on the toy icon is really a probing look at gender roles circa 2023, with Barbie and Ken as chaste lovers turned antagonists. Feminism can be funny!
reviews.author: Christopher Lloyd

reviews.text: Throughout, the tone is playfully ironic with a side of preach. The biggest joy is in the endless runway of familiar doll costumes and the cotton candy sets. Robbie makes a genial ringmaster, with a terrific cast.
reviews.author: Thelma Adams

reviews.text: A very well-made, fun film with real heart and a wink but perhaps too many smooth areas.
reviews.author: Alan Corr

reviews.text: Barbie is perfect summer fun. It has meaningful moments and wacky fourth wall breaks that immerse you in the film. You dare to believe a Barbieland is a hop, skip, and high-heeled strut away.
reviews.author: DarkSkyLady

reviews.text: Margot Robbie oozes charm and radiance and pathos every moment of the film. The production design and costuming are sublimely fun, with pink plastic exclamation points marking every visual gaga and every nostalgic callback.
reviews.author: Roe McDermott

reviews.text: [Barbie is] two hours of dizzying, occasionally dazzling ideas, squished and squashed and stuck together without any real shape, sense or structure.
reviews.author: Chris Wasser

reviews.text: It’s both a flippy romp and a feminist outcry in shades of pastel pink. It’s a movie knowingly at odds with itself, and the disequilibrium, for all the film’s high cheer, sits uneasily on the screen.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: Barbie has a symbiotic view of how play becomes wearyingly, terrifyingly freighted with real-world meaning, which helps explain why the movie’s vision of the real world is somehow both whimsical and jaundiced.
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: Under normal circumstances, Barbie would be an overpowered, expensive vanity piece with a threadbare plot and lackluster dialog. Greta Gerwig, with a co-writing credit to Noah Baumbach, infuses real world existential crises into a cotton candy landscape.
reviews.author: MontiLee Stormer

reviews.text: Barbie is 114 minutes of clever, colorful chaos that’s also a sweet, self-referential salute to womanhood -- and the toy that was always there for young girls when they were figuring all that out.
reviews.author: Craig D. Lindsey

reviews.text: Who knew that an eleven and half inch tall plastic doll could hold the power to make me laugh, cry, and have deep meaningful thoughts about my overall existence.
reviews.author: Rosalie Kicks

reviews.text: Not enough comedy for 2 hours. It's not Barbenheimer. It's Barbie-occhio.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: Much like the titular doll, Gerwig gives us a product that appears perfect but is ultimately hobbled by its unintended contradictions.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig does a fantastic job in building different worlds, both in Barbieland and the real world. Margot Robbie is perfectly cast and I enjoyed her character's arc.
reviews.author: Michael Cook

reviews.text: Like its protagonist, Barbie is all the things all at once. Funny. Sentimental. Entertaining. Confrontational. Celebratory. Heartfelt. Heartbreaking. Kooky. Emotional.
reviews.author: Kathy Michelle Chacón

reviews.text: Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling are absolute standouts, embracing their roles with abandon and passion to create wonderfully relatable flawed characters in pursuit of meaning.
reviews.author: Chris Joyce

reviews.text: The movie always maintains an unabashed good mood.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: Gerwig's comical societal study and trippy trip fashions several surprises.  The biggest one might be Gosling's hilarious, scene-stealing performance.
reviews.author: Jeff Mitchell

reviews.text: Barbie is very entertaining in the moment, but like the dolls themselves, it feels like a movie that will be forgotten once the novelty wears off.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: Surprisingly mature and thoughtful, as well as deeper and wittier than you ever thought a Barbie movie could go, it’s both an escape and an emotional thesis. I guess it’s true; Barbie really can be everything.
reviews.author: Johnny Gayzmonic

reviews.text: You can feel the pressure to negotiate and justify Barbie's existence for today's audience getting in the way of a good time. If only Margot Robbie had the opportunity to let loose and have as much fun with it as Ryan Gosling and Kate McKinnon did.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: Barbie is one of the year's best films. Margot Robbie's Barbie character arc is beautiful and America Ferrara delivers the most memorable dialogue in the film, I will be seeing this movie multiple times!
reviews.author: Lauren Veneziani

reviews.text: The film may be candy-coated but it’s one barbed entertainment for discriminating adults.
reviews.author: Jeff York

reviews.text: A triumph of feminist filmmaking and perfecting queer appeal, leading to this being one of the year's best movies.
reviews.author: EJ Moreno

reviews.text: It manages to come across as both an ingenious pop-culture lampoon/celebration and an unpretentious but surprisingly heartfelt deep dive into the implications of the Barbie archetype.
reviews.author: M.V. Moorhead

reviews.text: A deliriously joy-filled social satire.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: Director Greta Gerwig takes the eternally popular Mattel doll and uses it to spin a masterful social satire.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: Delving into deeper topics, fleshing out a timely satire, rooting for womanhood while being full of beans, dance, music, charm and comedy, Gerwig's creativity knows no bounds.
reviews.author: Sukanya Verma

reviews.text: Gerwig shows that you can show off this cornerstone of capitalist meta commentary in technicolour, musical fun, while also exploring themes of girls' confidence, smashing the patriarchy, and finding one's real identity.
reviews.author: Shelagh Rowan-Legg

reviews.text: If you don't know much about Barbie, there is still fun to be had, but not nearly as much as for those in the know.
reviews.author: Tom Santilli

reviews.text: Robbie is a sunbeam of sweetness and determination, and Gosling, resplendent under blindingly blond hair, is her lovably clueless quasi-boyfriend.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: They made a Barbie movie for grown-ups about feminism and the patriarchy. Let that sink in for a moment.
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: Even when Greta Gerwig trips on her ambition to make this hot-pink fantasia more than the fun party of summer, you cheer her refusal to play it safe as she turns Robbie’s doubt-plagued Barbie and Gosling’s clueless Ken into a match made in movie heaven.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: The artisanship was Spectacular! The brilliance of Greta Gerwig is on full display. The performance and fun as well as enduring. The films has a thoughtful message on embracing “You” & all the wonderful things that make "You" who you are.
reviews.author: Elliott Collins

reviews.text: Audiences will be clamoring to embrace their unique versions of Barbie, Kens, or even Allans. Gerwig’s directorial prowess is unmatched. With a perfect score filmography, one can only wonder if her foot is arched beneath her shoe.
reviews.author: Kit Stone

reviews.text: Gerwigland is a hectic pastel trip.
reviews.author: Andiee Paviour

reviews.text: It's a bit busy, and ideas fly around so fast that it's hard for some of them to stick. But it's a funny, sharp movie, and one that addresses themes of womanhood more clearly than any movie I can remember.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Margot Robbie plays the main character in Barbie, but it’s Latina women—America Ferrera’s Gloria and onscreen daughter Sasha—that tug at the heartstrings the most.
reviews.author: Li Lai

reviews.text: Margot Robbie is perfectly cast in Greta Gerwig’s wacky and wildly imaginative comedy about Mattel’s superstar doll. It’s the kind of movie that the term ‘meta’ was coined for.
reviews.author: Russ Simmons

reviews.text: as I think about this colorful confection, I realize that women’s battle for equality – true equality – is an ongoing one that is still a long way from being won.
reviews.author: Robin Clifford

reviews.text: Barbie is working so frantically and exhaustingly to justify its own existence that at some point, top-like, it spins 360 degrees right back around to, “Wait, why are we here doing this again?”
reviews.author: Jason Adams

reviews.text: "It's diving into that imaginative play and you [the audience] are the one that's playing."
reviews.author: Lonita Cook

reviews.text: Gerwig’s imaginative and thought-provoking take on the material represents the best-case scenario for a major studio's toy line adaptation.
reviews.author: Victor Stiff

reviews.text: Pretty postmodernism in pink.
reviews.author: Jason Gorber

reviews.text: It’s a wild, hilarious, meta ride that will have you nostalgic for childhood in the midst of real-world issues.
reviews.author: Sarah Musnicky

reviews.text: Fabulous looking, superbly acted yet deeply troubling... and brought to you by Mattel. Coincidence?
reviews.author: Kim Hughes

reviews.text: Barbie is entertaining and often hilarious. While the story feels a bit unfocused at times, Gerwig effortlessly creates an authentic world that comes to life in an inventive way. Robbie and Gosling are perfect.
reviews.author: Austin Burke

reviews.text: But if it’s not the uncompromising bastion of feminist cinema we might have wished for, then Barbie still leaves plenty to commend as a laugh-out-loud, amiable, endearingly sincere, and extremely entertaining summer blockbuster...
reviews.author: Laura Potier

reviews.text: There are more than a few gut-busters that take this bizarre concept and run with it in surprising ways. But for every transcendent piece of humor, there are ten gags that don’t register.
reviews.author: Dan Scully

reviews.text: While there are great laughs and visuals, it's a case of the commentary leading the characters rather than the characters leading the commentary. When you forget the characters the film is supposed to be about are even in the film, there's a problem.
reviews.author: Doug Walker

reviews.text: “Barbie” is “My Barbie Life To Live” and “Two Or Three Things I Know About Barbie” and “Farewell to Language”...  blunt politics about objectification, capitalism and “sexualized capitalism” and patriarchy that would not be out of place in  “La chinoise.”
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: The Kens steal the show with…"I'm Just Ken," destined to go down in queer history alongside other classic homoerotic movie musical moments like "The Aggie Song" from "The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas," and "Take Off with Us" from "All That Jazz."
reviews.author: Frank J. Avella

reviews.text: Barbie might not be an overtly queer film, but at the end of the day, its campy heart owes a whole lot to the dolls.
reviews.author: Abby Monteil

reviews.text: Barbie is a fantasy comedy that doesn't take itself seriously for a second, but still has something very serious to say. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: While the film is often funny, clever, and insightful, it's also so over-crowded with ideas and subplots that it resorts to simply preaching its message to resolve the story.
reviews.author: Sean Chandler

reviews.text: Barbie is overblown fun with a feminist twist
reviews.author: Carla Renata

reviews.text: Barbie is a triumph. There’s so much happening in every corner of the frame, yet not so much that Gerwig ever loses focus on the characters populating her madcap realm of nonsensical imagination.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: Bright and colorful on the outside, but a full on journey through self acceptance and discovery on the inside. Whenever I need a good cry, I am going to turn to Barbie.
reviews.author: Tessa Smith

reviews.text: [Greta Gerwig] has crafted a film that is at once intelligent, funny, sexy and unexpectedly emotional.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: By the end of Barbie’s 114 minute runtime, which flies by, your face will ache from the laughing and smiling but your heart will hurt from the hurting and raging.
reviews.author: Charlotte Harrison

reviews.text: Barbie works because it balances a myriad of themes, and succeeds – against all odds. It manages to be funny, and irreverent, but also self-deprecating, and profound. At times it’s important, it can be poignant, and it can absolutely downright ridiculous.
reviews.author: Stefan Pape

reviews.text: Robbie’s uncanny likeness to the original Mattel blueprints for Barbie – along with her sheer likability in front of a camera – generates the right kind of feminised force field from which the film can continually draw power.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: Just about everything one could hope — both a critique and celebration of the enduring toy’s role in the lives of young girls over the years and a colorful-and-zany romp that never forgets to entertain.
reviews.author: Mark Meszoros

reviews.text: If you open up your heart to the weird and wonderful embrace of Greta Gerwig’s transcendent Barbie, you’ll be greeted by an audacious production design, swimming in exquisite film references and tender vulnerability.
reviews.author: Eric Marchen

reviews.text: Frantic, uncheerful, and graceless, Barbie symbolizes a culture that devalues childhood and goodness.
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig surprises with a comedy that manifests soul as funny as it is provocative with a looming Ryan Gosling.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Martínez

reviews.text: There’s of lot of zeitgeist appeasement going on here. But the production values are sensational and there are some excellent jokes, even if Ryan Gosling’s Ken leaves Margot Robbie’s Barbie standing. They should have called this "Ken."
reviews.author: Deborah Ross

reviews.text: Through using their otherness perspective, Barbie functions as a warning tale that mirrors the struggles of women living under the patriarchy to understand the learned behavior of humanity.
reviews.author: Jillian Chilingerian

reviews.text: The neatest trick is how Barbie, starring a pitch-perfect Margot Robbie, can simultaneously and smoothly both mock and admire its source material.
reviews.author: Jocelyn Noveck

reviews.text: Robbie spends so much time playing second fiddle to other characters that her emotional payoff ends up leaning on audience nostalgia more than it has any right to. Her Barbie is everything, and nothing at all.
reviews.author: Ian Thomas Malone

reviews.text: Between Gloria, Allan, Weird Barbie, and even Robbie's Stereotypical Barbie, the film's designated Pinocchio--she just wants to be a real woman--Gerwig has injected this corporate product with genuine feeling.
reviews.author: Kathy Fennessy

reviews.text: The movie perfectly balances humor and blockbuster drama. It has very moving messages about womanhood, self, and even life and death that will leave you teary, but it also has more than a few moments that will leave you cackling with delight.
reviews.author: Mey Rude

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig can really turn anything into gold and give you an existential crisis with it. This time gold came in pink.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: Despite it being radically different from her previous work in form and tone, Barbie has the Gerwig stamp. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Laura Pérez

reviews.text: Gerwig stuffs the 12-inch box Mattel gave her with ideas, flourishes, and twists until it bursts into a kaleidoscopic rainbow of confetti. The aftermath makes for a bit of a candy-colored mess, but the remnants on the floor are an unmistakable original.
reviews.author: David Crow

reviews.text: It's at its best in the beginning and the end, but the movie is undone by a middle section where gags give way to convention that constrains any attempts at subversiveness.
reviews.author: Chase Hutchinson

reviews.text: Is “Barbie” a fun time at the movie theater? Absolutely. Will it make you laugh, and maybe even tear up at points? For sure. Then the filmmakers, and Mattel, did their job.
reviews.author: Candice Frederick

reviews.text: Although the female archetypes through time are reflected explicitly through Ferrera's speech, the movie assimilates the demystifying effect of the word from its own political fabric. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Paula Vázquez Prieto

reviews.text: [T]he film is quite a bit of intelligent fun.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: A colorful exploration of a fashion doll having an existential crisis. It’s as weird as it sounds, which works well in favor of a movie happy to lean into absurdist comedy, wacky set pieces, and strong themes involving maturation and womanhood.
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: While the production design is pop, plastic, and shiny with hyper saturated colors, the social critique covers the place of a woman in the real world. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: Barbie has both style and substance, and while its story may get overactive and muddled in its last reel, Gerwig’s point of view on gender roles and the way that women are treated in society pulls few punches.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: Co-writers Greta Gerwig and Noah Baumbach deliver biting satire, taking a hot pink poker to sexism while never abandoning the comedy.
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: The entire current shifting cultural landscapes around men and women have never been more fascinating and are well-aired for younger audiences but bring little to the rest of us.
reviews.author: Stefan Kyriazis

reviews.text: An earnest feminist manifesto inside a barbed social satire inside an effervescent musical comedy, all designed in colors and textures so sumptuous they make 1950s Technicolor look desaturated.
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: Barbie herself never quite emerges as a flesh-and-blood character. That may be the movie’s fatal flaw.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: Barbie was Kenough. I was hoping for Kenmore.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: Yes, this strange, strange film is a big con, but it’s one you can’t help tipping a pink cowboy hat towards.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: 'Barbie' is more flexible - and funny - than you might think.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: Hands up, it’s the most creative, fun-loving, serious, and heartfelt movie I’ve seen this year, Greta Gerwig provides a cultured interpretation of being a woman in an imaginary, perfect world--Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling shine brightly in their roles.
reviews.author: Sarah Knight Adamson

reviews.text: The cast is game, but the script is lame. That doggerel about sums it up.
reviews.author: Christopher Llewellyn Reed

reviews.text: Given that the Barbie movie could have been a plastic and hollow commercial with no human identity, designed to unabashedly reinforce the toy brand, it’s refreshing to see a filmmaker apply her critical perspective.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: “Barbie” is also absolutely bonkers — and I was 100 percent on board with wherever it took me. I sat in the theater beaming with a grin not even a bright-pink bazooka could wipe off my face.
reviews.author: Odie Henderson

reviews.text: Barbie subverts all expectations for a hilarious, wild, unexpectedly emotional but most importantly a generational-defining empowering film for so many! Robbie is Excellent as always & Ryan Gosling Ken is just as great as you’d expect!
reviews.author: Zach Pope

reviews.text: Despite a few parts of the screenplay being clumsy and meandering, Barbie is a nearly pitch-perfect comedy in its blend of satire and social commentary. The production design, costume design, and casting are impeccable. The musical numbers are a bonus.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: Barbie the movie is poignant, touching, and will have you in awe by the end thanks to its commentary, the design, and the brilliant performances.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: Gerwig's film is "good enough," but in a perfect Barbie world, it would have been better, and made Ken a sidekick, not a co-star.
reviews.author: Gary M. Kramer

reviews.text: 'Barbie' lives up to its full po-Ken-tial.
reviews.author: Brian Lloyd

reviews.text: The whole film feels like a first draft of ideas and concepts in desperate need of refinement.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: ... A refreshing movie that entertains and goes by quickly if you partake in the game it proposes. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mikel Zorrilla

reviews.text: Barbie could have easily just been a fish out of water narrative. To be clear, it is that, but Barbie is interested in more than simply exploring how an anatomically incorrect woman with impossible body proportions fits into the messy real world.
reviews.author: Joe Lipsett

reviews.text: Barbie is quite possibly Gerwig's best film to date. It is insightful, hilarious, and packed with thoughtful commentary as well as an incredible amount of Easter eggs and one-liners that will reward audiences.
reviews.author: Nicole Drum

reviews.text: Barbie is a movie about existentialism. It's about questioning who we are... Behind the glitter and the bleach-blonde bouffants, Barbie and Ken are on opposite but equal journeys to personal enlightenment.
reviews.author: Lucy Ford

reviews.text: Gerwig’s Indie sensibilities and ear for quirky dialogue have crafted a world that is beautifully tangible. Be prepared to throw away caution and laugh out loud in this genuinely enjoyable cinematic experience.
reviews.author: Rachael Harper

reviews.text: It is likely the strangest Hollywood blockbuster you’ll see this year, and like The Lego Movie, it’s much more than the crass corporate product you might expect.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: The movie’s silly-smart pleasures are almost endless...
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: Barbie blends frivolous fun with thought provoking social commentary.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: Margot Robbie, Ryan Gosling can't save story captured by man-hating agenda.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: Somehow, director Greta Gerwig has struck a balance between unhinged whimsy, deep humanity and comedic bliss.
reviews.author: Emily Zemler

reviews.text: There’s an enjoyable movie buried under all that hype, especially for those receptive to unwrapping the neatly packaged real-world themes while watching Barbie strut her stuff...
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: It would be easy to lean into the camp aspects of the role, but Robbie takes on Barbie with a wide-eyed earnestness.
reviews.author: Esther Zuckerman

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's delightful comedy adventure is bolstered by Robbie and Gosling's impeccable performances, a top-notch ensemble cast, and a witty screenplay.
reviews.author: Sandie Angulo Chen

reviews.text: What gives me hope was the response of the preview screening audience with whom I saw “Barbie” – mostly women, mostly young – who laughed with a sense of release that had a giddy, liberating edge to it.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: For the most part, Barbie achieves great comedy with sharp commentary. It doesn’t completely stick every landing, but the fun ride of the film is adventurous enough that most viewers won’t mind some of the minor shortcomings.
reviews.author: Chauncey K. Robinson

reviews.text: What could’ve been just another piece of disposable entertainment has somehow become the most fascinating and sure to be talked about films of the year.
reviews.author: Andrew Parker

reviews.text: Girl power, woman power, a feminist war-cry wrapped up in a pink bow and full of real heart and seriously lols; it's a Barbie World, and you should be in it.
reviews.author: Kate Rodger

reviews.text: Above all else, it feels like Mattel hates it when the doll leaves the confines of the box, gets a new name, is played with, and transforms into something beyond their creation, even as they poke and prod Gerwig to suggest otherwise.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: The movie felt too crowded.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

reviews.text: It is a film that says "girls who love pink can also be feminists”.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: "a summer movie that has more depth than you might expect, and demands to be seen on the big screen to take in every ounce of all the incredible craftsmanship in front of and behind the camera. "
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Barbie is pop-art done perfectly.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: Gender satire & eye-popping color make it shine. With fun musical numbers & constant hilarity, Robbie & Gosling ace their roles. However, the film lacks depth & fails to critique the corporate machine effectively. Entertaining but falls short on substance
reviews.author: Aaron White

reviews.text: Gerwig artfully outwits the eventual think pieces and potential backlash by making her "Barbie" a rumination on the ineffable mysteries of life and the Kobayashi Maru that is being a woman.
reviews.author: Dominic Griffin

reviews.text: Barbie is a riot with an incredible script and stellar cast. Gerwig continues to solidify herself as one of the best filmmakers working today.
reviews.author: Jonathan Sim

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig models her guiding ethos in her art, utilizing the imperfect vessel of popular branded entertainment to create a splashy spectacle inquiring about gender and grace.
reviews.author: Marshall Shaffer

reviews.text: Can Barbie prevent a Ken-tastrophe and shoot down the patriarchy? This Barbie-cue of Mattel's eternally young miss is lovingly done with fuchsia-infused feminism. Margot Robbie is stereotypically Barbie-licious and Ryan Gosling has the right Kenergy.
reviews.author: Jana Monji

reviews.text: The sets and costumes are built on a bedrock of Barbie history and archives, with plenty of fun Easter eggs for Barbie fans that won’t feel too alienating to newcomers.
reviews.author: Shannon Campe

reviews.text: Phenomenal film. Margot Robbie, Ryan Gosling, Greta Gerwig and Noah Baumbach knock this one out of the park, creating an instant classic. A fantastic, positive take on feminism that also works as entertainment. Hopefully a strong awards contender!
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: Gerwing hasn't sold out and has ventured into mainstream with refreshing ease and freedom that deserves to be celebrated. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Batlle

reviews.text: [Gerwig] triumphs again in the delightfully silly, self-aware if slightly overstuffed Barbie
reviews.author: Lisa Trifone

reviews.text: The satire gets diluted in an uneven second act, and perhaps insecurely, the third act concludes in a series of speeches and dramatic scenes that reiterate points already made more organically and intelligently at the beginning. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Benjamín Harguindey

reviews.text: Barbie may be scratching at something interesting in satirising the easy ride mediocre men have in the world, but it’s also one of the bigger ironies that it only really comes alive as a movie when Ken gains some agency...
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: Gerwig and Baumbach waste no time in racing through the scenes you might anticipate... Their exuberantly eccentric fairy tale has some of the dark, angst-ridden surrealism of Charlie Kaufman and the meticulous eeriness of Stanley Kubrick.
reviews.author: Nicholas Barber
