reviews.text: ... A hamster wheel of relentless identity crises, musical numbers, tears, tantrums, bland feminist speeches, questionable acting from the huge cast and Ken suddenly turning into a deranged ex-boyfriend.
reviews.author: Dulcie Pearce

reviews.text: I was expecting a sharp, feminist satire from cowriter (with Noah Baumbach)/director Greta Gerwig, but instead she’s given us a battle of the sexes comedy…offers a lot of laughs and is colorful entertainment, but its message is muddled.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: ... A summer movie so unexpected and so unpredictable that it will demand repeat viewings and future essays galore.
reviews.author: Tori Brazier

reviews.text: Everything about Barbie is crafted with both mass appeal and personal insight, much like the doll, resulting in a movie that knows how to please.
reviews.author: Tatiana Hullender

reviews.text: Well, I'm pleased as pink punch to say that "Barbie" exceeds all expectations, and with all the love to "Lady Bird" and "Little Women," is Gerwig's best film yet
reviews.author: BJ Colangelo

reviews.text: It’s difficult to accept Barbie as a satire when the filmmakers’ earnest enjoyment of the cars, the houses, the outfits, and even the toy food feels much more indulged than any philosophical reckonings.
reviews.author: Fran Hoepfner

reviews.text: It's a Barbie world you'll be more than happy to have visited, even as it confounds.
reviews.author: Aisha Harris

reviews.text: What a gorgeous and fascinating mishmash this is.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: Weird and wonderful, it’s one of the funnest and funniest movies ever made – and is brilliantly spearheaded by actress and producer Margot Robbie, along with writer-director Greta Gerwig.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: A fun and clever enough comedy and twist on the world’s most famous doll with wonderful production values, a charming Margot Robbie and an absolute hilarious Ryan Gosling.
reviews.author: Jimmy Cage

reviews.text: Ultimately, Barbie is so many things: a stereotype, a toy, an idea; a vessel of imagination; a cultural relic. But in Gerwig’s trusted hands, this is Barbie like you’ve never seen her before.
reviews.author: Emily Maskell

reviews.text: It’s a true work of imagination that will surely spark vital conversation while dazzling through its visual splendor
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: Barbie is a dazzling, frothy meta-comedy that’s very much in on the joke. Its varnished artificiality is a powder-pink Trojan Horse with which the film smuggles its very real commentary on gender politics.
reviews.author: Yasmin Omar

reviews.text: ...a feminist fairy tale with lots on its mind about the modern world and the gender roles within. That, and it’s also exceptionally silly and funny.
reviews.author: Andrew Gaudion

reviews.text: Life in plastic is fantastic indeed: Barbie is a sharp, hilarious and joy-contagious satire of gender roles.
reviews.author: Mireia Mullor

reviews.text:
It’s a wild and wacky pink-hued comedy-musical about the world’s most famous doll.
Like The Lego Movie before it, Barbie is a meta-movie that both wallows in nostalgia and challenges it. In that sense, it’s mission accomplished.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: For the first 30 minutes or so Barbie is a fun, feather-weight satire...Then the stuff about patriarchy kicks in and the film turns into a thinly disguised #metoo rant, trading comedy for man-bashing and a lot of confused point-scoring about sexism.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: BARBIE is energizing, hilarious, full of bright and mesmerizing colors, all while being marvelously entertaining.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: BARBIE is a comedy that is simultaneously rollicking, affecting and political --- immensely enjoyable and worth at least a second viewing.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig’s Barbie is often good and sometimes great, but it always feels like it’s fighting to be itself rather than the movie Warner Bros. and Mattel Films want.
reviews.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

reviews.text: Film as Soul Revolution, that is what Greta Gerwig has accomplished. There are many surprises and perfect casting, as well as song, dance and laughs. And it becomes a celebration … yes of BARBIE … and how accepting who we are is magic power. Barbie rules!
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: Barbie is a beautiful bubble gum dream, turning everyone and everything into a wonderful Barbie world.
reviews.author: Leo Brady

reviews.text: The funniest film of the year! Its also very clever in the way it celebrates & critiques the whole idea & concept of Barbie. Such a wonderful satire, led by a heartfelt performance by Margot Robbie and a hilarious Ryan Gosling. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: A candy-coloured, dizzying delight that's not only genuinely hilarious and wonderfully entertaining but bitingly subversive and shrewdly pertinent.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: While the script might have bitten off more than it had any intention of chewing, Barbie is still good fun. It is easy to watch and rewards audience for paying attention to the art direction, so long as they don’t look too closely at film’s hollow thesis.
reviews.author: Deirdre Crimmins

reviews.text: While it’s not as biting or sharp as it imagines itself to be, Barbie’s plastic parade of camp and goofy hijinks slowly give way to the kind of tender, insecure emotion that Gerwig is so damn good at.
reviews.author: Hoai-Tran Bui

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig's pink-hued film adaptation of the eponymous, billion-selling toy line is a brilliant satire that thoughtfully explores relationship dynamics. It's also knockdown funny with heart, epic dance numbers, and gleefully torches patriarchal norms.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: Barbie is beautiful, hilarious, smart, and utterly singular.
reviews.author: Joey Magidson

reviews.text: A fascinating movie, even if it is occasionally a little frustrating.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: The film perhaps asks us all to look into many of the passed down ways we are told what gender roles are, how to act when someone is assertive with their boundaries, and why, like the role of Barbie herself, needs a new definition.
reviews.author: Murjani Rawls

reviews.text: Barbie is a modern fairy tale that speaks to the current moment where individuality is under attack and does it with humor, optimism and depth. I laughed, I cried, I didn’t stop smiling until the credits rolled.
reviews.author: Joey Morona

reviews.text: As toy commercials go, it's definitely the best one ever made.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: Barbie is a deconstruction and love letter to the icon, with great set pieces, choreography, and style. Greta Gerwig continues to show why she’s one of the best directors working today, while Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling shine as always.
reviews.author: Sheraz Farooqi

reviews.text: One of the best films of the year. A funny, witty, empowering and crowd-pleasing delight brimming with warmth, tenderness and wisdom. It's destined to become an all-time classic.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: What could've been a glorified commercial, Greta Gerwig expertly turns into a subversive, radical, existential satire with sharp humor, that says what it wants, without ever apologizing for what it wants to be. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Rivera Rubio

reviews.text: Barbie looks camp right in the eye and turns it into a hot pink-splashed post-modern meta exploration of existentialism, feminism, the patriarchy and masculinity packaged in a satirical surreal musical comedy homage to classic cinema.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: Gerwig’s artistic voice feels stifled here, and repackaged as an empowerment product to be sold on shelves, but with the necessary accessories—the truth and nuance of her previous work—sold separately.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: The humor masks the glaring issues with the narrative and plot, which helps to keep the film as the crowd-pleaser the people were promised. Just don’t look for a deeper meaning behind Pinocchio's—or rather Barbie’s—delusions of grandeur.
reviews.author: Maggie Lovitt

reviews.text: A fine, fun romp with lots of thought-provoking aspects that should allow it to appeal as much (or maybe even more) to older women than the movie’s presumed younger target audience.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: Barbie is an inventive slice of cinema that’s bursting with creativity and comedy.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: The film ultimately loves Barbie (and women), and celebrates her positivity with a beautiful, realistic lens.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: Combining the meta jokiness with a heap of motivational sincerity is no easy task, but Barbie is a very charming success.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: Despite plucky stars Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling, and a stylized production design for the ages, the movie itself is a mystery shrouded in a puzzle. Who is this movie for? Beats me.
reviews.author: Roger Friedman

reviews.text: In Gerwig’s capable hands, even a movie about the one of most popular toys of all time eludes expectations at every turn. Barbie is her mainstream masterpiece, a dazzling dream that will touch the souls of everyone who sees it.
reviews.author: Coleman Spilde

reviews.text: The comedy is routinely effective, but the overarching storyline leaves much to be desired.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: In this existential exegesis on what it means to be a woman, and a human, Gerwig reflects our world back to us through the lens of Barbie, and in doing so, delivers a barbed statement wrapped in a visually sumptuous & sublimely silly cinematic confection
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: The zaniness of Barbie, combined with Gerwig’s interest in skewering the patriarchy, sometimes makes the movie a baggy, tonally dissonant viewing experience. But for the most part, she achieves a pleasing balance between the silly and the serious.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: A soulful film underneath all the persistent fuchsia. One that has heart and ambition as well as abundant beauty, inside and out.
reviews.author: Tomris Laffly

reviews.text: I did not expect this to be a movie about Ken -- and more importantly, a movie Ryan Gosling steals with such glorious aplomb that I can’t even be that mad at him for it.
reviews.author: Maddy Myers

reviews.text: … a fun little flick that manages to be quirky and engaging, for the most part
reviews.author: Anthony O'Connor

reviews.text: It is completely bananas, and that just might be something we need right now.
reviews.author: Stephen Romei

reviews.text: For all that Mattel will profit from Gerwig’s name, there’s little here of her private reserve of outstanding sensitivity, messiness and appreciation for the beauty of... “the real world”. In their place are merely hollow overtures to feminism.
reviews.author: Ann Manov

reviews.text: Ultimately, Barbie is a film that is a must watch for it’s impressive cinematography and impeccable craftsmanship, but its storyline is drowned out by too many themes all fighting for the front seat.
reviews.author: Lillie Rohan

reviews.text: Barbie is about as personal and idiosyncratic a creative statement as you could conjure within the studio system.
reviews.author: Kimberley Jones

reviews.text: A vivid but heavy-handed thematic fantasy-comedy adventure.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: Ultimately, Barbie the film suffers from the same problem as Barbie the character: it ends up flat-footed. The film is buoyed by jokes yet heavy with speeches.
reviews.author: Anwen Crawford

reviews.text: Barbie is brought to life by filmmaker Greta Gerwig in this immensely meta movie that’s as full of social commentary as it is fabulous camp.
reviews.author: Joshua Mackey

reviews.text: It’s neither a full-on farce nor a sharp feminist takedown, but a weird amalgam of the two that tries to wear its intellectual colours lightly.
reviews.author: Helen Hawkins

reviews.text: What really makes this comedy click are the stellar performances, from the lead role on down. This is the funniest cast I’ve seen in some time.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: Barbie is some real top-tier summer cinema.
reviews.author: Julian Lytle

reviews.text: While the overly safe Super Mario Bros Movie from earlier this year took its IP so seriously it was like a remedial history lesson, Barbie is a worthwhile movie about a brand. Women can do it all.
reviews.author: Rich Juzwiak

reviews.text: This is a wonderfully fun watch that somehow manages to simultaneously celebrate and satirise the Barbie brand, its feminism and girliness pairing like gorpcore sandals with a floaty pink skirt.
reviews.author: Alice Saville

reviews.text: Gerwig’s “Barbie” is, delightfully, more than Kenough.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: "Barbie," director and co-writer Greta Gerwig’s summer splash, is a dazzling achievement, both technically and in tone. It’s a visual feast that succeeds as both a gleeful escape and a battle cry.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: Setting aside the question of whether an air-conditioned multiplex in peak summer is the best setting to ponder feminism, however, Barbie makes an admirable effort to introduce the concept to wide swaths of audiences the world over.
reviews.author: Lisa Wong Macabasco

reviews.text: Barbie is both a master’s thesis on feminism and an Austin Powers-esque romp.
reviews.author: Chandler Levack

reviews.text: An ambitious study of the human condition via popular product, Barbie thinks right outside of the box. Definitely worth playing with.
reviews.author: Jane Crowther

reviews.text: This is a truly original work -- one of the smartest, funniest, sweetest, most insightful and just plain flat-out entertaining movies of the year.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Gerwig's latest cinematic feat is moving, daring, and intelligent all while being one of the most creative movies of the year. This movie isn't just fun to watch: it's sharp, witty, and captures the reality of the femme experience.
reviews.author: Annie Banks

reviews.text: Barbie is a very clever attempt -- perhaps an exceedingly clever attempt -- to breathe new meaning and significance into the doll.
reviews.author: Tom Gliatto

reviews.text: It's a thoughtful, funny film that cares about what Barbie means to people and it argues that Barbie -- like human beings -- makes mistakes but is pretty great, anyway.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: The film isn’t about the doll so much as about a feeling many people (especially women) understand deeply -- the feeling of faking your way through your life because of how we are told to feel and how we have to overcome it.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: "The script contains unexpected subtlety, particularly during the tender moments which pack an emotional punch"
reviews.author: Alex Flood

reviews.text: Barbie is a masterwork. It’s as thoughtful as it is funny with a few snags here and there but on the whole, feels like a triumph in IP movie-making.
reviews.author: Jason Flatt

reviews.text: “Barbie” is an impressive and original work of the imagination.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: Barbie is not only built for this moment, it's built to last, just like the doll at its center. This is a Barbie you'll want to hold onto and cherish for quite some time.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: Has a few rough edges, but Gerwig continues to dance to her own beat.
reviews.author: Hannah Strong

reviews.text: Much like Diamond Dazzle Barbie, all facets of the Barbie film shine spectacularly.
reviews.author: Britany Murphy

reviews.text: Barbie is Greta Gerwig’s best film to date and one that serves as a love letter to womanhood.
reviews.author: Scott Menzel

reviews.text: Barbie is one of the most inventive, immaculately crafted and surprising mainstream films in recent memory -- a testament to what can be achieved within even the deepest bowels of capitalism.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: There’s a streak of defensiveness to Barbie, as though it’s trying to anticipate and acknowledge any critiques lodged against it before they’re made, which renders it emotionally inert despite the efforts at wackiness.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: “Barbie” is a lovingly crafted blockbuster with a lot on its mind, the kind of feature that will surely benefit from repeat viewings (there is so much to see, so many jokes to catch) and is still purely entertaining even in a single watch.
reviews.author: Kate Erbland

reviews.text: As expected, Greta Gerwig’s live-action BARBIE movie is filled with subversive feminist messaging but Gerwig balances the truth bombs with comedy. Margot Robbie is a perfect Barbie and Ryan Gosling steals the show with his himbo Ken-energy.
reviews.author: Lupe Rodriguez Haas

reviews.text: A big movie can still have big ideas in 2023. Even a Barbie movie. Especially a Barbie movie.
reviews.author: David Fear

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig delivers a new kind of ambitious and giddily entertaining blockbuster that boasts two definitive performances from actors already in their stride. Life after Barbie will simply never be the same again.
reviews.author: Beth Webb

reviews.text: Robbie takes an archetype long dismissed as an airheaded caricature and, moment by deeply felt moment, teases and fleshes her out.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig’s latest feature film might be her boldest, but it’s also, unfortunately, her messiest.
reviews.author: Allyson Johnson

reviews.text: Gerwig’s film – while still fundamentally being a summer comedy adventure about the Barbie toy line – is far from the blunt-force cash grab many of us feared. In fact it’s deeply bizarre, conceptually slippery and often roar-out-loud hilarious.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Greta Gerwig’s Barbie is a dream house of cheers and tears. A whimsical and emotional journey of self-discovery and growth. No longer can we say she’s everything. He’s just Ken. They are everything.
reviews.author: David Gonzalez

reviews.text: However smartly done Gerwig’s Barbie is, an ominousness haunts the entire exercise. The director has successfully etched her signature into and drawn deeper themes out of a rigid framework, but the sacrifices to the story are clear.
reviews.author: Lovia Gyarkye

reviews.text: Barbie is really an insightful exploration of humanity, the meaning of life and the cognitive dissonance of a woman living in the patriarchy, all with a really big heart and style to spare.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: A pure delight! Bright, bubbly, effervescent, hilarious. One of the funniest movies in years — and one of the most emotional, touching and meaningful. Clever parody, punchy commentary! Totally not what you expect!
reviews.author: Dave Lee

reviews.text: Gerwig and her creative collaborators not only give the formerly inanimate figure a sparkling personality and a pastel-shellacked pop-art playground, they also deliver genuinely meaningful sentiments surrounding the complexities of gender politics.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: Gerwig has made the kind of family film she surely wishes had been available to her when she was a girl, sneaking a message (several of them, really) inside Barbie’s hollow hourglass figure. That’s an admirable achievement.
reviews.author: Peter Debruge

reviews.text: It's Gerwig's care and attention to detail that gives Barbie an actual point of view, elevating it beyond every other cynical, IP-driven cash grab.
reviews.author: Devan Coggan

reviews.text: Barbie could’ve just been a commercial, but Gerwig makes this life of plastic into something truly fantastic.
reviews.author: Ross Bonaime

reviews.text: The Mattel brand looms large here, but Gerwig, whose directorial command is so fluent she seems born to filmmaking, is announcing that she’s in control.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: "Barbie" manages to straddle a vibrant film filled with enough Easter eggs and nods to the doll's 64-year history to necessitate a second watch with a self-critical piece for those who believe Barbie is a detriment to feminism.
reviews.author: Kirsten Acuna

reviews.text: “Barbie” is an exhausting, spastic, self-absorbed and overwrought disappointment.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: A new modern summer classic that is as indulgent as it is sharp...it's fantastic.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: A masterful exploration of femininity and the pressures of perfection.
reviews.author: Alyssa Mora

reviews.text: The things that are good about Barbie end up being steamrollered by all the things this movie is trying so hard to be. Its playfulness is the arch kind. Barbie never lets us forget how clever it’s being, every exhausting minute.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: Barbie is one of the best pictures of the year but it's not surprising when one takes a look at the talent behind and in front of the camera.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: It’s over the top, Day-Glo in every way possible, silly and goofy. It’s also smart and thoughtful and depressing in a speak-truth-to-power, zeitgeisty kind of way — a critique of toxic masculinity and more.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: Struggles in the real world, but the Barbie Land stuff is gold. Gosling delivers one of the greatest recent comic performances.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: It is maybe down to Gerwig’s confidence and generosity as a feminist film-maker that she gives all the best lines to Ryan Gosling, who is allowed to steal the whole film.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: "Barbie" convinces you of its grander purpose towards defining personal identity without assigned labels and accessories. Every kittenish joke, dabbled concept, and twinkling dream floating in this fantasy is tethered to the human condition.
reviews.author: Don Shanahan

reviews.text: Barbie is a template for how not to write a crowd-pleasing Hollywood feature. Ms. Gerwig and Mr. Baumbach are accomplished indie filmmakers who make poor choices to flesh out these characters.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: While Gerwig and co-writer Noah Baumbach may couch this self-discovery narrative in powder pinks and unrelenting pep, their message is authentic and acerbic: an urgent feminist call to arms wrapped up in a hugely entertaining popcorn movie.
reviews.author: Nikki Baughan

reviews.text: There is plenty in Barbie to be delighted by, even moved by.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: At its best, the movie is like the kind of high-end restaurant that serves great food in the playful guise of favourite childhood desserts. The pleasures of that -- and the chutzpah of doing it at blockbuster scale -- are to be applauded.
reviews.author: Danny Leigh

reviews.text: “Barbie” is the movie our world needs right now.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: A clever take on growing up as seen through the point of view of the doll itself, like Toy Story and The Lego Movie. Barbie complicates this paradigm with the broader societal woes plaguing women.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: The film is at once a journey of self-actualization and a testament to female solidarity.
reviews.author: Greg Nussen

reviews.text: Dumps a lot of tones and ideas out of its toybox but manages to connect the disparate parts, resulting in an all-too-rare thoughtful blockbuster.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: Barbie is a magic trick, a stellar example of a filmmaker taking a well-established bit of corporate IP and using it to deliver a message loudly and clearly — while also delivering a giddy, silly, and hilarious time.
reviews.author: Liz Shannon Miller

reviews.text: With "Barbie," Greta Gerwig delivers a bold, brilliant, & beautiful dissection of both the lasting yet complicated legacy of this doll & the evolving roles men & women occupy in our world, aided by Margot Robbie & Ryan Gosling's note-perfect performances.
reviews.author: Zoë Rose Bryant

reviews.text: Throughout the film’s running time, I just kept thinking to myself I can’t believe this exists and I can’t believe they got away with it.
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: Barbie is a pink-soaked summer bash that invites you to indulge in Gerwig’s creative extravaganza, and it’s a party well worth attending.
reviews.author: Jeff Nelson

reviews.text: While Barbie focuses on the world’s most iconic doll and society’s relationship to her constructed meaning, Gerwig slyly makes a movie about what it means to be alive.
reviews.author: Sophia Ciminello

reviews.text: The crucial partnership here is the one between director and performer, Gerwig and Robbie; anything Gerwig and Baumbach’s verbally dexterous script requires, from Barbie’s first teardrop to the final punchline, Robbie handles with unerring precision.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: 'Barbie' is everything that the promise of a Mattel Cinematic Universe is not: fresh and full of life and promise for the art of cinema.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

synopsis: To live in Barbie Land is to be a perfect being in a perfect place. Unless you have a full-on existential crisis. Or you're a Ken.
